titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Collection in the Library of Congress
titlestmt.author: Prepared by Manuscript Division staff

controlnote.p: Encoded in EAD3 : Encoded Archival Description (EAD), Version 3 : Release: 1.1.1 : Release Date: 2019-12-16. Validating against latest version of schema.

citation.linktitle: DACS in HTML on SAA website

descriptivenote.p: DACS was used as the primary description standard.

maintenanceevent.eventdescription: Finding aid encoded by Manuscript Division staff.

did.head: Collection Summary

descriptivenote.p: Collection material in English with French, Spanish, and Chinese.

did.abstract: Journalist, author, environmentalist, and animal welfare advocate. Writings, oral history transcripts, and photographs in both physical and digital formats. Material in physical format also include correspondence, notebooks, diaries, newspaper clippings, research files, and printed matter. All primarily relate to Free’s journalistic career after 1940.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The papers of Ann Cottrell Free were given to the Library of Congress by Elissa Blake Free in 2019. Numerous additions were given by her between 2019 and 2022.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The papers of Ann Cottrell Free were arranged and described by Nate Scheible with the assistance of Tom Bigley, Andrea Briggs, Katie Duvall, Miles Lawlor, Amanda Loeb, Sara Ludewig, and Tammi Taylor in 2022.

Digital files were received as part of the Ann Cottrell Free Papers on a variety of storage media, each of which was assigned a unique digital ID number. Use the digital ID number to request access copies of the files associated with each media. A description of the standard processes taken on all born digital records can be found in the Processing History Note: Born Digital Collection Material at https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.mss/eadmss.digital.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: Audiovisual items have been transferred to the Motion Picture, Broadcasting, and Recorded Sound Division. Among the transferred items are audiotapes of interviews, oral histories, conversations, and speeches by Free. Patrons are encouraged to contact the Motion Picture, Broadcasting, and Recorded Sound Division in advance of a research visit.

separatedmaterial.head: Other Repositories
separatedmaterial.p: Additional records related to Ann Cottrell Free's oral history conducted by Recording Animal Advocacy can be found at the Columbia Center for Oral History at Columbia University.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p:
Related collections in the Manuscript Division include the James Free Papers (see https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.mss/eadmss.ms008052) and Ruby A. Black Papers (see
https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.mss/eadmss.ms010063).

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Copyright in the unpublished writings of Ann Cottrell Free in these papers and in other collections in the custody of the Library of Congress is reserved. Consult reference staff in the Manuscript Division for further information.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of Ann Cottrell Free are open to research. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use. Access to digital content is available onsite only in the Manuscript Reading Room and requires advanced notice. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting.

accessrestrict.head: National Security Classified Information
accessrestrict.p: Government regulations control the use of national security classified items in this collection. Manuscript Division staff can furnish information concerning access to and use of classified material.

phystech.head: Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Digital files were created in a Windows operating system, version is unknown. The content is primarily text files in .doc and .pdf formats and image files in .jpg and .tiff formats. Files in .indb and .indd formats created in the program InDesign are not accessible. However, the text from these files is viewable in related .pdf files.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container or digital ID number, Ann Cottrell Free Papers, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Ann Cottrell Free (1916-2004) span the years 1854-2018, with the bulk of the material dating from 1935 to 2000. The collection documents Free’s personal life and professional career as a journalist, author, environmentalist, and animal welfare advocate. The papers are primarily in English, with French, Spanish, and Chinese. The collection is organized into eight series: Personal File, Correspondence, Speeches and Writings, Subject File, Photographs, Notebooks and Diaries, National Security Classified Information, and Oversize.

The collection focuses on both Free’s personal life and professional career. The bulk of the collection is arranged by subject and reflects file groupings and folder titles created and maintained by Free. As a result, the collection is highly interconnected with related topical files found in multiple locations within and across series. Prior to donation to the Library of Congress, Free’s daughter, Elissa Blake Free, also arranged some of the material, sometimes including personal notes to provide greater context to the files. Some personalized or unconventional folder headings were placed in quotation marks to reflect Free’s original terminology and language used throughout the collection. The collection reflects the many topics Free was passionate about and explored in her writing throughout her life. Prominent topics include animal welfare, the environment, nature, civil rights, the plight of refugees, and the empowerment of women.
The collection’s series are listed and briefly described below. A fuller description of each series and a list of its contents can be accessed in the series descriptions within the container list.
The Personal File series primarily contains biographical material that provide an overview of Free’s life and career.
The Correspondence series comprises personal and professional correspondence from Free’s family, friends, and colleagues, the bulk of which spans from 1937 to 1997.
The Speeches and Writings series comprises articles, books, short stories, speeches, and essays written by Free.
The Subject File series largely consists of working and background files that document the breadth of topics Free wrote about throughout her career.
The Photographs series comprises prints, negatives, and scrapbooks that mostly document Free, her family, her friends, and her travels in the late 1940s.
The Notebooks and Diaries series contains Free’s notebooks and diaries spanning from her college years in the late 1930s until her death in 2004.
The remaining series contain Oversize and National Security Classified Information material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Papers
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in eight series:

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

persname.part: Cottrell, Emily Blake, approximately 1889-1950. Emily Blake Cottrell papers.
Free, Elissa Blake, 1955- Elissa Blake Free contextual notes.

corpname.part: Great Britain. Royal Navy. Women's Royal Naval Service (1939-1993)
United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.
United States. Animal Welfare Act of 1970.
United States. Army. Women's Army Auxiliary Corps.

scopecontent.p: The Personal File series primarily contains biographical material that provides an overview of Free’s life and career. This is largely reflected in transcripts of detailed oral history interviews with Free regarding her animal advocacy efforts, experiences as a female journalist in the 1940s, and work in China with the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration. Other biographical material includes awards, biographical sketches, articles about Free, résumés, and files related to her birth, marriage, and death. Of particular interest in the series is a file of notes and correspondence related to sessions with psychologist Elaine W. Cotlove in which Free discusses and analyzes her romantic relationships with women in the 1930s and 1940s. The series also contains material related to Free's family, mostly the papers of her mother, Emily Blake Cottrell, including correspondence, notebooks, and diaries. Free’s correspondence with her mother, however, is maintained primarily in the Correspondence series. While the series contains biographical and autobiographical material, similar files can be found throughout other series in the collection, mostly in Free's writings, diaries, and notebooks.

Material types include résumés, transcripts, awards, certificates, clippings, business cards, correspondence, recipes, and notes. Some textual material is in digital format. The file structure of the digital content maintained as received.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by material type or subject.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series comprises personal and professional correspondence from Free's family, friends, and colleagues, the bulk of which spans from 1937 to 1997. The correspondence is wide-ranging, touching on many aspects of Free’s life and career. Details of her travels in the 1940s are reflected within the series in letters to Emily Blake Cottrell and John Oudine, in a subject file on India, and in a compilation of letters to and from her travel companion, Verna Mae Feuerhelm Cody. Other files of note include letters related to Free’s romantic relationships with Margaret Johnson, Claude James, and Isabelle Ziegler. A file of “early job letters” reflects Free’s experiences with sexism in the journalism profession from the 1930s to 1950s. The series does not represent the entirety of correspondence in the collection as letters are filed throughout other series. Researchers are encouraged to consult the Subject File series for correspondence related to specific subjects.
Material types include letters, memoranda, invitations, greeting cards, telegrams, faxes, postcards, photographs, and writings.

arrangement.p: Arranged into a chronological file, a name file, and a subject file.

White House invitations and greeting cards, 1941-2001

scopecontent.p: The Speeches and Writings series comprises articles, books, short stories, poems, speeches, and essays written by Free. The bulk of the writings spans from 1942 to 1999. In addition to published and unpublished writings, the files contain drafts, working files, and background on Free’s publishing company, Flying Fox Press. Files are mostly arranged by type of writing, with the exception of a group of files Free arranged by subject that include a largely unorganized mix of articles, drafts, notes, and fragments. Additional files containing both published and unpublished writings, namely Free’s writings on the Animal Welfare Act, Rachel Carson, China, the Marshall Plan, Albert Schweitzer, and Eleanor Roosevelt, can be found in the Subject File. Notable unpublished manuscripts in this series mostly focus on animal welfare topics. Free’s unpublished manuscript about her experiences in China in the 1940s and her biography of Rachel Carson can be found in the Subject File. Some writings arranged by subject also include photographs, most notably the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps and Women's Royal Navy Service files.

Material types include articles, poems, essays, books, speeches, short stories, outlines, notes, clippings, drafts, correspondence, photographs, and advertisements. Some textual and visual material and images are in digital formats. The file structure of the digital content maintained as received.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by material type or subject.

scopecontent.p: The bulk of the collection, the Subject File series largely consists of working and background files that document the breadth of topics Free wrote about throughout her career. Most of the files in the series relate to animals and animal welfare issues including humane societies, animal legislation, laboratory animals, farm animals, pets, wildlife, ethics, and specifically the relationships between humans and animals. Other significant files focus on topics Free revisited throughout her life and wrote about in detail. These include extensive files on famine and politics in post war China, Eleanor Roosevelt and her relationship with the female press corps, the “reverence for life” philosophy of Albert Schweitzer, and Rachel Carson and her impact on environmental activism. Many of these files contain writings, correspondence, notes, speeches, diaries, photographs, and research files. The series also documents Free’s involvement with the Albert Schweitzer Fellowship, Mrs. Roosevelt’s Press Conference Association, National Press Club (previously the Washington Press Club), Rachel Carson Council, Society of Woman Geographers, and many local and national humane societies and animal welfare associations. Other noteworthy individuals documented within the series include Elisabeth De Croÿ, Zhou Enlai, Ellen Glasgow, Temple Grandin, Lister Hill, Mary Hornaday, Ruby Black, Edouard Nies-Berger, Malvina Stephenson, Christine Stevens, and Ernest P. Walker.
Material types include clippings, notes, correspondence, writings, printed matter, and photographs.

scopecontent.p: The Photographs series comprises prints, negatives, and scrapbooks that mostly document Free, her family, her friends, and travels in the late 1940s. The photographs represent a mix of professional portraits and snapshots. The travel photographs are extensive and document Free’s travels with Verna Mae Feuerhelm Cody in 1946 and 1947 throughout Asia, Europe, and the Middle East. Of note from this trip are many photographs from India taken around the time the Indian Independence Act went into effect in 1947. A detailed itinerary of this trip can be found in the "Around the world with Ann and Verna" file in the Subject File series. Other photographs documenting Free’s travels include those related to her position with the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration in China and work in Europe reporting on the Marshall Plan. The oral history photographs include noteworthy images handpicked by the donor to accompany transcripts found in the Personal File series. Researchers should be aware that photographs exist in other series within the collection and were retained within those files to maintain appropriate context.
Material types include prints, negatives, and scrapbooks.

scopecontent.p: This series contains Free’s notebooks and diaries spanning from the early 1930s until her death in 2004. Some notebooks are labeled according to topic, but most are chronological, documenting both professional and personal aspects of her life. In most cases, there is little distinction between the personal and professional, with many notebooks featuring notes on articles, drafts, interviews, and research as well as more domestic matters including appointments, grocery shopping, and house maintenance. Noteworthy diaries include those reflecting her time in China, India, and Europe in the 1940s. Also of note are notebooks related to Rachel Carson and a group of notebooks surrounding the birth of her daughter, Elissa Blake Free, in 1955.
Material types include notebooks, diaries, journals, daybooks, and note cards.

The National Security Classified Information series contains one incomplete report prepared for the Secretary of State for Public Affairs providing an analysis of stereotyped concepts of the United States perpetuated in the Soviet Union and neighboring countries.

did.unittitle: Russia, United States stereotypes in the Soviet Union, report, circa 1950 (Container 181, same heading)
